results.title: Convoy of life
results.creator_credit: Doss Jenkins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Doss Jenkins’ driving instructor was not fond of female drivers and was strict but she passed and soon became part of a long convoy transporting American goods over Australia. The journey was a gruelling and hot 108 weeks on the road, travelling at 50km an hour. Doss reflects on the things that kept her going, the games she played and the friends she made. This group of ladies still have an annual reunion due to the strong bond created by the journey.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Doss Jenkins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: When war came to Australia
results.creator_credit: Bill Hosking, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A recent visit to Darwin with his son reminded Bill Hosking of the time that war came to Australia. As one of the men who defended Darwin during that time, he was instructed to keep the details of the attack secret. In 1942, Bill Hosking joined up and was shipped up to train in the Northern Territory. It was during this time that the air raids on Darwin took place. Bill shares his experiences because he believes that not many people today know the story of how Australia came under attack.

results.title: Hope
results.creator_credit: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Les Jones heard those two magic words “It’s over”, he starting thinking about his future after the war. The middle of three generations of army men, he was part of the last major action in the Pacific part of World War II. As well as being uncertain about his future, Les also thought about those that wouldn’t be returning with him. It is with the thoughts of these lost soldiers in mind, that Les considers war and whether or not there is a better way to solve conflict.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Why two numbers
results.creator_credit: Jayne Mooney, Noel O'Brien, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: The O’Brien family have served in the army since the 1800s. Noel O’Brien, himself a member of the service, delves into the military history of his family and, in particular, of his father. Francis Charles O’Brien had two regimental numbers to his name and Noel wanted to find out the reason. As a result, he discovers something of his father’s personality, a larrikin who got himself into trouble, but was courageous enough to always be there for his mates.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jayne Mooney, Noel O’Brien, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: So far, so good
results.creator_credit: Joel Hagan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A growth spurt sent Joel Hagan into the arena of sports. Finding out he was naturally good at Australian rules, Joel has travelled around Australia, playing football and, later, rugby. Joel’s coaches taught him to be quick off the mark and not to wait for the ball, to go out and get it. These words have inspired Joel, not only in sports but in all aspects of his life and have given him the ambition to pursue a career in journalism in the future.

results.title: What makes me, me
results.creator_credit: Robbie Palm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: One of Robbie Palm’s favourite things is fishing at the creek of his nan’s property. Even though he goes to boarding school in Brisbane, he returns during school holidays to fish. He has been taught by his family the techniques and it is this, and when he plays the Didgeridoo that Robbie feels most connected to his culture. When he plays, he feels proud and watched by his family, both current and past.

results.title: Our trip to Sydney
results.creator_credit: Bryce O'Neill-Baker, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bryce O’Neill-Baker tells of the time when he was asked if he wanted to go to Sydney for a short trip. The next day, he joined a bus with family members and others from his community to visit Sydney for the weekend. As well as the normal sightseeing, he also got to experience the NAIDOC festival and warmly shares the effect this time had on his family.

results.title: DST July 09 presents...
results.brief_description: ACMI Digital Storytelling interviews the six participants of the Foundation of Young Australians workshop in July 2009. They are asked questions in regard to the process, what they learned and the experience of telling their stories. This is also intercut with footage from the actual workshop and serves as a behind the scenes documentary to capture the process of Digital Storytelling as well as the impact on the participants.

results.title: My family
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: To Malcolm Dotoi, his family includes what he would call his extended family, his cousins and grandfather. They provide support, guidance and inspiration and have helped him to develop into a youth leader. His grandfather, a tribal elder, has taught Malcolm about his connection to the land and to the spiritual world and how all these things have contributed to who Malcolm is today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.
